channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q & A: Evan Osnos on the ‘Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China’
item.description: In a discussion of his new book on China, the New Yorker staff writer talks about parallels to America’s Gilded Age and his attempts to reconcile the country’s seeming contradictions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Prosecutor Seeks 30-Day Psychiatric Evaluation for Pistorius
item.description: The move by the prosecutor Gerrie Nel followed defense testimony that Mr. Pistorius suffered from “general anxiety disorder.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: At Least 14 Die as Migrant Boat Headed for Italy Sinks off Libyan Coast
item.description: Italian officials would not estimate the number of people who were still missing, but at least 200 were rescued from the Mediterranean Sea.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Dirty Dancing in Egypt
item.description: Belly dancers are both loved and reviled in an Egypt that finds sensuality to be dangerously subversive.
item.dc:creator: By ALAA AL ASWANY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Loyal Bunch
item.description: Never mind corruption, our clownish president and the general drift, in South Africa political habits die hard.
item.dc:creator: By BONGANI MADONDO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: China Isn’t Overtaking America
item.description: By most meaningful yardsticks, China is still less economically powerful than the United States.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL A. LEVI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Horse at the Heart of Chinese-Turkmen Relations
item.description: In addition to valuable natural gas projects, the Turkmen president brought a more glamorous gift for the Chinese president: a rare breed of horse known in China as the “sweats blood” horse.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China was presented with a horse from President Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow of Turkmenistan.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Teaching Liberation to Pakistan’s Girls
item.description: We can transform “sex education” from something dirty into a vital tool of progress.
item.dc:creator: By BINA SHAH

item.title: Google Must Honor Requests to Delete Links, E.U. Court Says
item.description: Europe’s highest court said that Google must, in some cases, grant users of its search engine a so-called right to be forgotten that includes deletion of links to embarrassing legal records.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Germany Renews Diplomatic Effort to Ease Ukraine Crisis
item.description: The German foreign minister arrived in Kiev to promote dialogue as battle lines hardened between the government and separatists in the east of the country.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Police Detain Contributor to U.S.-Based Website
item.description: Xiang Nanfu, 62, is accused of fabricating stories about topics including organ harvesting and police beatings. His detention is the latest in hundreds of arrests in a crackdown on expression on the Internet.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Former Israeli Premier to Serve 6 Years for Bribery
item.description: Ehud Olmert was sent to prison on corruption charges by a judge who likened him to a “traitor” for taking bribes while mayor of Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israel's former Prime Minister Ehud Olmert at the Tel Aviv District Court on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Warning Spreads as Beijing Clamps Down on Illegal Modeling
item.description: More than 60 people on nonwork visas were detained and had their passports confiscated after a sting in Beijing, according to advocates for models’ rights.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A model at a technology fair in Beijing. Foreign models commonly enter China on tourist visas and illegally find work.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bus Driver’s Actions Credited With Saving Lives in Fire
item.description: The driver’s actions, filmed by a camera system, come as international attention has focused on the responsibilities of transportation personnel, particularly after the South Korean ferry incident.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Nuclear Talks Will Confront Iran’s Future Capability to Enrich Uranium
item.description: American negotiators say the key is to leave Iran with a face-saving nuclear structure but one small enough to overcome Congressional objections.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Uruguayan Leader Meets With Obama to Talk Trade and Human Rights
item.description: President José Mujica’s visit to the White House came as the South American country seeks new markets for its commodities exports.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Armed Police Begin Antiterrorism Patrols in Beijing
item.description: Beijing has begun special armed patrols in the city, with as many as 13 paramilitary police officers deployed in each of 150 patrol vehicles in an effort to deter terrorist attacks and “mass incidents,” according to multiple Chinese news reports.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Members of the Special Weapons and Tactics team walking past an armored vehicle during an antiterrorism drill in Beijing.

item.title: Authorities in Spain Make Arrests in Fatal Shooting of Politician
item.description: Isabel Carrasco, the head of the provincial council in León, was shot at least three times as she crossed a bridge near her home.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Provincial Council Leader Shot
item.description: A regional politician from Spain’s governing Popular Party was shot dead in the northern city of León on Monday, prompting the country’s main parties to suspend campaigning.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: World Briefing: Nominee for Egypt Ambassador Post
item.description: The White House moved Monday to fill the long vacant post of the United States ambassador to Egypt by nominating Robert Stephen Beecroft, a career diplomat.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Attack on Former Official Fails
item.description: Eleven people have been confirmed dead and 20 others wounded after a car bomb exploded on Monday at a cafe frequented by government officials in the town of Baidoa, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: A Death Draws Attention to Afghan Police Methods
item.description: There are persistent reports of innocent people being tortured and killed by the police in Kandahar, creating a backlash that local people say has fed support for the Taliban.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Negligence Charges Brought in Quebec Derailment and Fire
item.description: The railway and three employees have been charged in the accident, which killed 47 people and burned much of a town last July.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russia Keeps Its Distance After Ukraine Secession Referendums
item.description: Instead, the Kremlin used the results, which indicated overwhelming support for secession from Kiev, to press for some manner of negotiated autonomy.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Alexander Malyhin, the chief of the commission that organized the referendum, spoke with journalists on Monday in Luhansk.

item.title: Life vs. Traffic: De Blasio Looks Toward Sweden for Road Safety
item.description: The rate of roadway deaths in Sweden is at an international low. Now the country’s approach faces perhaps its stiffest test: the streets of New York City.
item.dc:creator: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Swedish Parliament adopted Vision Zero in 1997.
